title: How to Make a Scented Garland

steps.headline: Pre-heat your oven to 200°F (94°C).
Slice some oranges into ¼-inch (0.64-centimeter) thick slices.
steps.description: How many oranges you end up using depends on your final design and how long you want the final garland to be. Plan on using about 11 oranges for a 4-foot (1.22-meter) garland.

steps.headline: Bake the oranges in the oven for 4 hours, turning them every hour.
steps.description: You can place them directly onto the rack in the oven. Avoid using a baking sheet, as this will trap too much moisture and will prevent the orange slices from drying out properly. Every hour, use a pair of tongs to turn the orange slices. If you'd rather not dirty up your oven, place a metal rack on top of a baking sheet, then place the orange slices on the rack.

steps.headline: Buy a big bag of bay leaves and empty it into a large bowl.
steps.description: Again, how many bay leaves you end up using will depend on how long your garland is, and how you choose to arrange the oranges, bay leaves, and cinnamon sticks on it. You will need about 250 bay leaves for a 4-foot (1.22-meter) garland. It might be a good idea to go through the bay leaves first and pluck out any damaged or broken ones. Save those for cooking.

steps.headline: Consider drilling holes through the middle of your cinnamon sticks.
steps.description: You can always just tie the twine around the cinnamon sticks instead, but they will stay on the garland better if you use holes instead. Plan on using about 18 cinnamon sticks for a 4-foot (1.22-meter) garland. Drill the holes from the curled/seamed side using an electric drill and a small drill bit.

steps.headline: Cut a 4-foot (1.22-meter) garland piece of twine, thread it through a yarn needle, and tie one end into a small loop.
steps.description: The loop does not have to be very big; something big enough for your finger to slip though will be plenty. The loop will help prevent everything from sliding off. It will also allow you to hang the garland up.

steps.headline: Start stringing your orange slices, bay leaves, and cinnamon sticks onto the twine.
steps.description: Slip your needle through the a cinnamon stick first, then pierce it through the center of an orange slice, followed by 5 to 8 bay leaves. Add another orange slice, 5 to 8 more bay leaves, and then a final orange slice. Slide everything towards the end of the string. If you did not make holes in the cinnamon sticks, simply wrap the twine around the center of the stick and tie it into a double knot.

steps.headline: Repeat this pattern until you run out of items or the garland reaches the length you want.
steps.description: You can also vary the pattern, if you'd like, use more of certain items, or use fewer of others. Remember to leave a few inches/centimeters at the end of your twine.

steps.headline: Tie another loop at the end of the twine.
steps.description: At this point, you can hang your garland from hooks or nails in doorways, above fireplace mantles, or over windows. You can also wrap them around your Christmas tree!

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 285°F (140°C) and line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Mix together the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Pour 1 cup (100 grams) of all-purpose flour into a large mixing bowl, then add ½ cup (150 grams) of salt. Next, add 2 to 4 tablespoons of ground cinnamon, 1 teaspoon of ground allspice, ½ teaspoon of ground cloves, and 2 teaspoons of ground ginger. Stir them together with a whisk until they are all evenly combined.

steps.headline: Stir in the water until the mixture turns to dough.
steps.description: Pour in a little bit of water, and stir it in with a rubber spatula. Stir in some more water, and mix again. You may end up using up to 1 cup (240 milliliters) of water. Avoid using too much more, or the dough will turn out too sticky.

steps.headline: Turn the dough onto a lightly-floured surface and knead it some more.
steps.description: The dough should be soft and smooth. If it is sticky, add some more flour, and knead it some more.

steps.headline: Consider adding some color.
steps.description: You can make your garland all one color, or many different colors. Start by separating your dough into clumps—one for each color. Next, add a few drops of food coloring into each clump, then knead it in until the color turns consistent. Fall colors, such as red, orange, and yellow work great for this. You can always paint the pieces after you bake them, but the paint may cover up the wonderful aroma.

steps.headline: Roll the dough out.
steps.description: Lightly flour a smooth surface, and roll the dough out using a rolling pin. Try to get the dough to be about ¼-inch (0.64 centimeters) thick.

steps.headline: Cut the dough into shapes using cookie cutters.
steps.description: Hearts and stars are very popular, but you can also use circles, leaves, or other shapes.

steps.headline: Poke two holes into the center of each ornament.
steps.description: Use a straw or knitting needle to punch the holes; keep them about ½ to 1 inch (1.27 to 2.54 centimeters) apart from each other. If you'd like a touch of extra fragrance and design, stick whole cloves, pointy-side-down, into your ornaments.

steps.headline: Transfer the ornaments to your prepared baking sheet, then bake them for 2 to 3 hours.
steps.description: After 1 hour, use a spatula to turn the ornaments over. Return them to the oven, and let them baking for another hour, or until they are completely dry. Don't raise the temperature. This will cause the dough to rise and form bubbles.

steps.headline: Take the ornaments out of the oven, and let them cool.
steps.description: If the holes got covered up, gently open them back up by twisting a wooden skewer or knitting needle through them.

steps.headline: Consider decorating your ornaments.
steps.description: Although not necessary, this can make your garland look prettier. Try not to get too carried away, however! Once you have decorated your pieces, let them dry. For fancier ornaments, decorate them using glitter and glue. For rustic ornaments, glue some simple, 4-hole buttons onto them.

steps.headline: Cut some ribbon, yarn, or twine for your garland, then thread it through a yarn or tapestry needle.
steps.description: If you choose to use ribbon, be sure to use the thinnest kind you can find. How long you cut your string depends on how long you want your garland to be. Most garlands will be about 4 feet (1.22 meters).

steps.headline: Thread your string through your first ornament.
steps.description: Take an ornament, and push the needle up through the first hole, then down through the second. Drag the ornament along the string until it is a few inches/centimeters from the end.

steps.headline: Continue threading the ornaments onto the ribbon or cord.
steps.description: Leave some space between each ornament. If you decorated your ornaments, make sure that they are facing the same direction.

steps.headline: Tie small loops into each end of your garland, then hang your garland up.
steps.description: You can hang it from hooks or nails over a window, doorway, or fireplace mantle. You can also wrap it around a Christmas tree instead.

text: Making a Dried Orange Garland Pre-heat your oven to 200°F (94°C).  Slice some oranges into ¼-inch (0.64-centimeter) thick slices. How many oranges you end up using depends on your final design and how long you want the final garland to be. Plan on using about 11 oranges for a 4-foot (1.22-meter) garland. Bake the oranges in the oven for 4 hours, turning them every hour. You can place them directly onto the rack in the oven. Avoid using a baking sheet, as this will trap too much moisture and will prevent the orange slices from drying out properly. Every hour, use a pair of tongs to turn the orange slices. If you'd rather not dirty up your oven, place a metal rack on top of a baking sheet, then place the orange slices on the rack. Buy a big bag of bay leaves and empty it into a large bowl. Again, how many bay leaves you end up using will depend on how long your garland is, and how you choose to arrange the oranges, bay leaves, and cinnamon sticks on it. You will need about 250 bay leaves for a 4-foot (1.22-meter) garland. It might be a good idea to go through the bay leaves first and pluck out any damaged or broken ones. Save those for cooking. Consider drilling holes through the middle of your cinnamon sticks. You can always just tie the twine around the cinnamon sticks instead, but they will stay on the garland better if you use holes instead. Plan on using about 18 cinnamon sticks for a 4-foot (1.22-meter) garland. Drill the holes from the curled/seamed side using an electric drill and a small drill bit. Cut a 4-foot (1.22-meter) garland piece of twine, thread it through a yarn needle, and tie one end into a small loop. The loop does not have to be very big; something big enough for your finger to slip though will be plenty. The loop will help prevent everything from sliding off. It will also allow you to hang the garland up. Start stringing your orange slices, bay leaves, and cinnamon sticks onto the twine. Slip your needle through the a cinnamon stick first, then pierce it through the center of an orange slice, followed by 5 to 8 bay leaves. Add another orange slice, 5 to 8 more bay leaves, and then a final orange slice. Slide everything towards the end of the string. If you did not make holes in the cinnamon sticks, simply wrap the twine around the center of the stick and tie it into a double knot. Repeat this pattern until you run out of items or the garland reaches the length you want. You can also vary the pattern, if you'd like, use more of certain items, or use fewer of others. Remember to leave a few inches/centimeters at the end of your twine. Tie another loop at the end of the twine. At this point, you can hang your garland from hooks or nails in doorways, above fireplace mantles, or over windows. You can also wrap them around your Christmas tree! Making a Salt Dough Garland Preheat your oven to 285°F (140°C) and line a baking sheet with parchment paper.  Mix together the dry ingredients. Pour 1 cup (100 grams) of all-purpose flour into a large mixing bowl, then add ½ cup (150 grams) of salt. Next, add 2 to 4 tablespoons of ground cinnamon, 1 teaspoon of ground allspice, ½ teaspoon of ground cloves, and 2 teaspoons of ground ginger. Stir them together with a whisk until they are all evenly combined. Stir in the water until the mixture turns to dough. Pour in a little bit of water, and stir it in with a rubber spatula. Stir in some more water, and mix again. You may end up using up to 1 cup (240 milliliters) of water. Avoid using too much more, or the dough will turn out too sticky. Turn the dough onto a lightly-floured surface and knead it some more. The dough should be soft and smooth. If it is sticky, add some more flour, and knead it some more. Consider adding some color. You can make your garland all one color, or many different colors. Start by separating your dough into clumps—one for each color. Next, add a few drops of food coloring into each clump, then knead it in until the color turns consistent. Fall colors, such as red, orange, and yellow work great for this. You can always paint the pieces after you bake them, but the paint may cover up the wonderful aroma. Roll the dough out. Lightly flour a smooth surface, and roll the dough out using a rolling pin. Try to get the dough to be about ¼-inch (0.64 centimeters) thick. Cut the dough into shapes using cookie cutters. Hearts and stars are very popular, but you can also use circles, leaves, or other shapes. Poke two holes into the center of each ornament. Use a straw or knitting needle to punch the holes; keep them about ½ to 1 inch (1.27 to 2.54 centimeters) apart from each other. If you'd like a touch of extra fragrance and design, stick whole cloves, pointy-side-down, into your ornaments. Transfer the ornaments to your prepared baking sheet, then bake them for 2 to 3 hours. After 1 hour, use a spatula to turn the ornaments over. Return them to the oven, and let them baking for another hour, or until they are completely dry. Don't raise the temperature. This will cause the dough to rise and form bubbles. Take the ornaments out of the oven, and let them cool. If the holes got covered up, gently open them back up by twisting a wooden skewer or knitting needle through them. Consider decorating your ornaments. Although not necessary, this can make your garland look prettier. Try not to get too carried away, however! Once you have decorated your pieces, let them dry. For fancier ornaments, decorate them using glitter and glue. For rustic ornaments, glue some simple, 4-hole buttons onto them. Cut some ribbon, yarn, or twine for your garland, then thread it through a yarn or tapestry needle. If you choose to use ribbon, be sure to use the thinnest kind you can find. How long you cut your string depends on how long you want your garland to be. Most garlands will be about 4 feet (1.22 meters). Thread your string through your first ornament. Take an ornament, and push the needle up through the first hole, then down through the second. Drag the ornament along the string until it is a few inches/centimeters from the end. Continue threading the ornaments onto the ribbon or cord. Leave some space between each ornament. If you decorated your ornaments, make sure that they are facing the same direction. Tie small loops into each end of your garland, then hang your garland up. You can hang it from hooks or nails over a window, doorway, or fireplace mantle. You can also wrap it around a Christmas tree instead.
sentences: Making a Dried Orange Garland Pre-heat your oven to 200°F (94°C).
Slice some oranges into ¼-inch (0.64-centimeter) thick slices.
How many oranges you end up using depends on your final design and how long you want the final garland to be.
Plan on using about 11 oranges for a 4-foot (1.22-meter) garland.
Bake the oranges in the oven for 4 hours, turning them every hour.
You can place them directly onto the rack in the oven.
Avoid using a baking sheet, as this will trap too much moisture and will prevent the orange slices from drying out properly.
Every hour, use a pair of tongs to turn the orange slices.
If you'd rather not dirty up your oven, place a metal rack on top of a baking sheet, then place the orange slices on the rack.
Buy a big bag of bay leaves and empty it into a large bowl.
Again, how many bay leaves you end up using will depend on how long your garland is, and how you choose to arrange the oranges, bay leaves, and cinnamon sticks on it.
You will need about 250 bay leaves for a 4-foot (1.22-meter) garland.
It might be a good idea to go through the bay leaves first and pluck out any damaged or broken ones.
Save those for cooking.
Consider drilling holes through the middle of your cinnamon sticks.
You can always just tie the twine around the cinnamon sticks instead, but they will stay on the garland better if you use holes instead.
Plan on using about 18 cinnamon sticks for a 4-foot (1.22-meter) garland.
Drill the holes from the curled/seamed side using an electric drill and a small drill bit.
Cut a 4-foot (1.22-meter) garland piece of twine, thread it through a yarn needle, and tie one end into a small loop.
The loop does not have to be very big; something big enough for your finger to slip though will be plenty.
The loop will help prevent everything from sliding off.
It will also allow you to hang the garland up.
Start stringing your orange slices, bay leaves, and cinnamon sticks onto the twine.
Slip your needle through the a cinnamon stick first, then pierce it through the center of an orange slice, followed by 5 to 8 bay leaves.
Add another orange slice, 5 to 8 more bay leaves, and then a final orange slice.
Slide everything towards the end of the string.
If you did not make holes in the cinnamon sticks, simply wrap the twine around the center of the stick and tie it into a double knot.
Repeat this pattern until you run out of items or the garland reaches the length you want.
You can also vary the pattern, if you'd like, use more of certain items, or use fewer of others.
Remember to leave a few inches/centimeters at the end of your twine.
Tie another loop at the end of the twine.
At this point, you can hang your garland from hooks or nails in doorways, above fireplace mantles, or over windows.
You can also wrap them around your Christmas tree!
Making a Salt Dough Garland Preheat your oven to 285°F (140°C) and line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Mix together the dry ingredients.
Pour 1 cup (100 grams) of all-purpose flour into a large mixing bowl, then add ½ cup (150 grams) of salt.
Next, add 2 to 4 tablespoons of ground cinnamon, 1 teaspoon of ground allspice, ½ teaspoon of ground cloves, and 2 teaspoons of ground ginger.
Stir them together with a whisk until they are all evenly combined.
Stir in the water until the mixture turns to dough.
Pour in a little bit of water, and stir it in with a rubber spatula.
Stir in some more water, and mix again.
You may end up using up to 1 cup (240 milliliters) of water.
Avoid using too much more, or the dough will turn out too sticky.
Turn the dough onto a lightly-floured surface and knead it some more.
The dough should be soft and smooth.
If it is sticky, add some more flour, and knead it some more.
Consider adding some color.
You can make your garland all one color, or many different colors.
Start by separating your dough into clumps—one for each color.
Next, add a few drops of food coloring into each clump, then knead it in until the color turns consistent.
Fall colors, such as red, orange, and yellow work great for this.
You can always paint the pieces after you bake them, but the paint may cover up the wonderful aroma.
Roll the dough out.
Lightly flour a smooth surface, and roll the dough out using a rolling pin.
Try to get the dough to be about ¼-inch (0.64 centimeters) thick.
Cut the dough into shapes using cookie cutters.
Hearts and stars are very popular, but you can also use circles, leaves, or other shapes.
Poke two holes into the center of each ornament.
Use a straw or knitting needle to punch the holes; keep them about ½ to 1 inch (1.27 to 2.54 centimeters) apart from each other.
If you'd like a touch of extra fragrance and design, stick whole cloves, pointy-side-down, into your ornaments.
Transfer the ornaments to your prepared baking sheet, then bake them for 2 to 3 hours.
After 1 hour, use a spatula to turn the ornaments over.
Return them to the oven, and let them baking for another hour, or until they are completely dry.
Don't raise the temperature.
This will cause the dough to rise and form bubbles.
Take the ornaments out of the oven, and let them cool.
If the holes got covered up, gently open them back up by twisting a wooden skewer or knitting needle through them.
Consider decorating your ornaments.
Although not necessary, this can make your garland look prettier.
Try not to get too carried away, however!
Once you have decorated your pieces, let them dry.
For fancier ornaments, decorate them using glitter and glue.
For rustic ornaments, glue some simple, 4-hole buttons onto them.
Cut some ribbon, yarn, or twine for your garland, then thread it through a yarn or tapestry needle.
If you choose to use ribbon, be sure to use the thinnest kind you can find.
How long you cut your string depends on how long you want your garland to be.
Most garlands will be about 4 feet (1.22 meters).
Thread your string through your first ornament.
Take an ornament, and push the needle up through the first hole, then down through the second.
Drag the ornament along the string until it is a few inches/centimeters from the end.
Continue threading the ornaments onto the ribbon or cord.
Leave some space between each ornament.
If you decorated your ornaments, make sure that they are facing the same direction.
Tie small loops into each end of your garland, then hang your garland up.
You can hang it from hooks or nails over a window, doorway, or fireplace mantle.
You can also wrap it around a Christmas tree instead.
tyn_section: Drill and drill bit (optional, but recommended)
